sections.title: Grow Wealth, Reduce Taxes
sections.subtitle: Understand which accounts give you upfront deductions, tax-free growth, or both

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: Differences between traditional and Roth contribution strategies
How HSAs, FSAs, and 529s create targeted tax savings
Contribution limits, catch-up rules, and withdrawal penalties
Coordinating employer matches, vesting schedules, and investment choices

sections.title: Retirement Anchor Accounts
sections.content: Traditional 401(k) and IRA contributions reduce taxable income todayâ€”and taxes apply upon withdrawal. Roth variants flip the script: no deduction now, but withdrawals in retirement are tax-free if rules are met. Diversifying across pre-tax and Roth buckets gives future flexibility when managing tax brackets in retirement.

points.title: Health Savings Account (HSA)
points.description: Triple tax advantage: deductible contributions, tax-free growth, and tax-free qualified medical withdrawals.

points.title: Flexible Spending Account (FSA)
points.description: Use pre-tax dollars for healthcare or dependent care expenses, but watch the use-it-or-lose-it rules.

points.title: 529 College Savings
points.description: Invest after-tax dollars and enjoy tax-free growth for qualified education expenses; some states give tax deductions on contributions.

sections.title: Order of Operations
sections.content: Capture employer matches first, max out HSAs if eligible, then prioritize Roth or traditional accounts based on your current vs future tax outlook.

sections.title: Contribution Logistics
sections.content: Track annual IRS limits: in 2025, employees can contribute up to $23,000 to a 401(k) plus a $7,500 catch-up at age 50+. IRAs cap at $7,000 ($8,000 catch-up). HSAs allow $4,300 self-only/$8,550 family. Automate contributions across the year to avoid year-end cash flow crunches.

sections.title: Account Optimization Blueprint
steps: List every tax-advantaged account available (401(k), Roth IRA, HSA, FSA, 529).
Record contribution limits, employer matches, and deadlines for each.
Decide your mix of pre-tax vs Roth contributions based on current tax bracket and retirement projections.
Schedule automatic transfers aligned with payroll or monthly cash flow.
Review beneficiary designations and update them annually.

sections.title: Use Windfalls Wisely
sections.content: Direct bonuses or tax refunds into Roth IRAs or HSAs before lifestyle creep absorbs the cash.
